questions.text: A 28 y/o football player experiences sudden pain on the inside of his left knee after getting tackled while running with the ball. He reports feeling a pop and is unable to continue playing. O/E, there is swelling, tenderness along the medial joint line, and pain when attempting to flex the knee. Which of the following injuries is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Structures in the knee and injuries

Cruciate Ligaments
  • The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is more vulnerable than the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) due to rotational forces in football. (Options B&D ruled out)
  • Sudden direction changes can overstretch and tear the ACL.

Collateral Ligaments (Lateral & medial)
  • Less frequently injured but essential for side-to-side stability. (Option A ruled out)
  • Side tackles (severe adduction or abduction) can strain these structures, leading to tears or sprains.

Menisci
  • Medial Meniscus is more prone to injury than the lateral meniscus.
  • The medial meniscus attaches to the tibial collateral ligament- hence, it is more susceptible to tears from rotational forces.
  • Bucket-handle tears are common in athletes and are characterised by longitudinal meniscus tears due to pivoting and twisting in a slightly flexed knee.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding sustentaculum tali is correct. It is a shelf like projection, projecting from posterior surface of calcaneus. Superior surface of sustentaculum tali bears a facet for talus. Inferior surface of sustentaculum tali bears a groove for the tendon of flexor hallucis longus The medial surface of sustentaculum tali provides attachment to spring ligament and superficial fibres of deltoid ligament
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

questions.text: Which statement best describes the relationship of the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most medial structure crossing to the lateral side of the fossa.

options.label: B
options.text: It is deep to the popliteal artery and vein.

options.label: C
options.text: It lies lateral to the popliteal vessels crossing to the medial side.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not enter the popliteal fossa.

questions.correct_answer: C. It lies lateral to the popliteal vessels crossing to the medial side.

questions.text: A 35 y/o man is hiking on uneven terrain. As he steps on a rock with his right foot, his foot tilts inward, his medial arch elevates, and his foot becomes more rigid. This movement is best described as:
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

questions.text: A 30 y/o athlete reports sudden pain in the back of his left leg and an inability to push off the ground while sprinting. Examination reveals a significant weakness in plantar flexion. Which muscle is primarily responsible for the action of plantarflexion in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Movements

Muscles Involved

Nerve Supply

Clinical Aspects

Dorsiflexion (Extension)

Tibialis Anterior (Option A ruled out), Extensor Digitorum Longus, Extensor Hallucis Longus, Fibularis Tertius

Deep peroneal nerve

Foot drop due to deep peroneal nerve injury.

Plantarflexion (Flexion)

Tibialis Posterior, Flexor Digitorum Longus, Flexor Hallucis Longus (Deep); Gastrocnemius, Soleus, Plantaris (Superficial)

Tibial nerve

Achilles tendon rupture, weakness in plantarflexion causes difficulty walking, especially uphill or on stairs.

Eversion

Fibularis Longus, Fibularis Brevis (Option D ruled out)

Superficial peroneal nerve

Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve causes difficulty in foot eversion and ankle instability.

Inversion

Tibialis Anterior (Anterior compartment), Tibialis Posterior (Posterior compartment)

Tibial nerve

Weakness of inversion may contribute to flatfoot, pain along the medial foot, and instability.

questions.text: A 40 y/o woman presents with ankle instability and pain on the lateral side after rolling her ankle while walking on uneven ground. Examination reveals weakness in foot eversion and tenderness over the base of the fifth metatarsal. Which muscle is primarily responsible for foot eversion in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The lateral compartment of the leg

Muscles

Fibularis Longus

Fibularis Brevis

Attachment

Origin: Head and proximal two-thirds of the fibula, deep fascia, intermuscular septa, and sometimes the lateral condyle of the tibia.

Insertion: Base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform.

Origin: Distal two-thirds of the fibula, intermuscular septa.

Insertion: Tuberosity on the base of the fifth metatarsal.

Action
  • Eversion of foot
  • Plantar flexion of the ankle
  • Supports longitudinal and transverse arches of foot
  • Eversion of foot
  • Limits inversion, relieving strain on lateral ankle ligaments

Innervation

Superficial fibular nerve (L5, S1)

Superficial fibular nerve (L5, S1)

Clinical aspects
  • Risk of tendon dislocation if fibular retinaculum ruptures

Limits inversion, relieving strain on lateral ankle ligaments.

questions.text: A 25-year-old runner presents with pain along the front part of his right leg and difficulty in lifting the foot upwards after increasing his training intensity. O/E, he shows weakness in extending the big toe and foot drop. Which muscle is most likely affected in this patient, leading to his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Anterior compartment of the leg

Muscles

Attachments

Innervation

Action

Clinical aspects

Tibialis Anterior
  • Lateral condyle, proximal 1/2-2/3 lateral tibial shaft, interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto medial cuneiform and base of 1st metatarsal.

Deep fibular nerve (L4, L5)
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Inverts foot
  • Supports medial arch
  • Weakness: foot drop
  • Can cause shin splints.

Extensor Hallucis Longus
  • The middle half of the medial fibula and interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of the hallux.

Deep fibular nerve (L5)
  • Extends hallux
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Weakness: Difficulty extending the big toe.

Extensor Digitorum Longus
  • Lateral tibial condyle, proximal 3/4 medial fibula, interosseous membrane.
  • Tendons insert onto middle and distal phalanges of lateral 4 toes.

Deep fibular nerve (L5, S1)
  • Extends lateral 4 toes
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Weakness: Issues extending toes
  • Foot drop risk

Fibularis Tertius
  • Distal 1/3 medial fibula, interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Deep fibular nerve (L5, S1)
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Everts the foot
  • Absent in some individuals
  • Helps prevent foot drag in gait.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the ligaments of the hip joint. The fibrous capsule is made up of outer fibres which are longitudinal and inner circular fibres which are called zona orbicularis. Ligamentum teres femoris transmits the arteries to the head of femur. IIiofemoral ligament is inverted Y shaped ligament. The acetabular labrum helps in holding the femur in position.

A 35-year-old woman presents with pain and swelling in the prepatellar region of her left knee, which developed gradually over the past few weeks. She works as a housemaid and spends long hours kneeling on hard surfaces while cleaning floors. On physical examination, the knee is swollen, and there is tenderness over the anterior part of the knee. The swelling is soft and fluctuant, and there is no redness or heat over the area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which dermatome supplies the middle of the back of the thigh and leg?
questions.explanation:
Segmental innervation of skin of Lower Limb

Segments

Area

L1, L2, L3

The anterior aspect of the thigh from above downwards

L4

(Option C ruled out)

The medial aspect of the leg

L5

(Option D ruled out)

The lateral aspect of the leg and the medial side of the foot

S1

(Option A ruled out)

The lateral side of the foot and sole

S2

(Option B)

Middle of the back of the thigh and leg

S3,S4

Buttocks

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.explanation:
Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves. (Option A, C & D ruled out)
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
  • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
  • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: A 55 y/o man presents with difficulty walking and reports pain along the medial aspect of his foot. Physical examination reveals weakness in inversion and signs of flatfoot. Which muscle is primarily responsible for the inversion of the foot in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Movements of Inversion and Eversion

Inversion

Eversion
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Tibialis posterior
  • Flexor hallucis longus
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • Peroneus brevis
  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus tertius

Superficial group of muscles

Muscles

Attachments

Action

Nerve

Clinical aspects

Gastrocnemius
  • Origin: Medial and lateral condyles of the femur
  • Insertion:Calcaneal tendon
  • Plantar flexion of the foot
  • Flexion of knee

Tibial nerve (S1, S2)

Testing: Plantar flexion against resistance (knee extended).

Soleus
  • Origin: Posterior head and proximal fibula, soleal line of tibia, tendinous arch of soleus
  • Insertion: Calcaneal tendon
  • Primary plantar flexor
  • Stabilizes leg during standing

Tibial nerve (S1, S2)

Testing: Plantar flexion against resistance (hip and knee flexed).

Plantaris
  • Origin: Lower part of the lateral supracondylar line on the femur, oblique popliteal ligament
  • Insertion: Calcaneus (medial to calcaneal tendon)
  • Assists gastrocnemius in plantar flexion (less significant)

Tibial nerve

Minor role in foot mechanics.

Deep group of muscles

Muscles

Attachments

Action

Nerve

Clinical aspects

Popliteus
  • Origin: Lateral femoral condyle
  • Insertion: Posterior surface of tibia above the soleal line

Unlocks the knee by laterally rotating the femur on the tibia

Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1,)
  • Injury may lead to knee instability
  • Important in knee biomechanics.

Flexor Digitorum Longus
  • Origin: Posterior surface of the tibia (medial to tibialis posterior)
  • Insertion: Plantar surfaces of distal phalanges of toes 2-5
  • Plantar flexion of the ankle
  • Flexion of the distal phalanges of toes 2-5

Tibial nerve (L5, S1, S2)

The aberrant function may contribute to toe deformities (e.g., hammer toe).

Flexor Hallucis Longus
  • Origin: Distal two-thirds of the posterior fibula, interosseus membrane.
  • Insertion: Plantar surface of the base of the distal phalanx of the hallux
  • Plantar flexion of the ankle
  • Flexion of the hallux

Tibial nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Overuse in dancers may lead to tendinopathy (e.g., hallux saltans).
  • Important surgical landmark at the ankle to avoid neurovascular injury.

Tibialis Posterior
  • Origin: Interosseous membrane, posterior surface of tibia, fibula
  • Insertion: Navicular tuberosity, cuneiforms, bases of metatarsals 2-4
  • The principal inverter of the foot
  • Supports medial longitudinal arch

Tibial nerve (L4, L5)

Dysfunction can lead to a flat foot (pes planus) due to tendon elongation and attenuation of the spring ligament.

questions.text: Where does the popliteus muscle originate, and what is its nerve supply?

options.label: A
options.text: Medial condyle of femur; Femoral nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral condyle of femur; Tibial nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Lateral condyle of femur; Tibial nerve
questions.explanation:
Popliteus Muscle

Origin

Arises within the knee joint capsule from the anterior part of the popliteal groove located on the lateral condyle of the femur.

Insertion
  • The medial aspect of the head of the fibula via the popliteofibular ligament
  • Medial two-thirds of the triangular area above the soleal line on the posterior surface of the tibia.

Blood supply
  • Inferior medial and lateral genicular arteries
  • Posterior tibial artery and its branches.

Nerve supply
  • The branch of the tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1).

Actions
  • Medially rotates the tibia on the femur; when the tibia is fixed, it laterally rotates the femur.
  • It is the "unlocking" muscle of the knee by unlocking the locked knee by rotating the femur laterally during the initial stages of knee flexion.
  • It pulls the lateral meniscus posteriorly, preventing it from becoming trapped and compressed between the femoral and tibial condyles.

questions.text: A 30-year-old runner comes in with weakness when trying to lift his foot and numbness on the outside of his right leg after hurting his knee. Examination reveals weakness in dorsiflexion and tenderness over the lateral aspect of the popliteal fossa. Which of the following structures is most likely compressed in the popliteal fossa, leading to the patient's symptoms?
Which of the following correctly matches a boundary of the popliteal fossa with its associated structure?

options.label: B
options.text: Inferomedially - Medial head of the gastrocnemius

options.label: C
options.text: Roof of the popliteal fossa - Biceps femoris

options.label: D
options.text: Inferolaterally - Popliteal surface of the femur

questions.correct_answer: B. Inferomedially - Medial head of the gastrocnemius
questions.explanation:
Boundary

Structure

Superolaterally

Biceps femoris muscle (Options A&C ruled out)

Superomedially

Semimembranosus, semitendinosus

Inferomedially

The medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle.

Inferolaterally

The lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle and the plantaris muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the boundaries of the adductor canal?

options.label: A
options.text: Anteriorly bounded by the sartorius muscle, laterally by the rectus femoris.

options.label: B
options.text: Posteromedially bounded by adductor longus and adductor magnus.

options.label: C
options.text: Roofed by the iliotibial band and bounded posteriorly by the adductor brevis.

options.label: D
options.text: Medially bounded by the gluteus maximus and anteriorly by the vastus lateralis.

questions.correct_answer: B. Posteromedially bounded by adductor longus and adductor magnus.
questions.explanation:
Boundary

Structure

Anterolaterally

Vastus medialis muscle

Posteromedially

Adductor longus and adductor magnus muscles

Anteromedially (Roof)

Subsartorial fascia (dense fascia between vastus medialis and adductor muscles)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles forms the lateral part of the floor of the femoral triangle?

A 28 y/o male presents with knee pain and instability after a football injury. The Lachmann Test is performed to assess for an ACL tear. At what degree of knee flexion is the Lachmann Test typically performed?
questions.explanation:
Anterior Drawer Test

Lachmann Test

This is a test to detect injury to the anterior cruciate ligament.

This is another test to detect injury to the anterior cruciate ligament.

Procedure: The patient is positioned supine, with the knee being tested flexed to 80–90°, and passive forward traction is then applied to the tibia. (Option D ruled out)

Procedure: This test is considered better than the anterior drawer test.

 
  • In this test, the knee is maintained in 15° to 20° of flexion.
  • One hand supports the thigh just above the knee, while the other holds the upper tibia.
  • The degree of anterior glide assesses the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

questions.text: A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency after a sports injury involving a sudden pivot on his left knee. An MRI reveals a tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Which statement regarding the knee ligaments is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral collateral ligament attaches to the patella.

options.label: C
options.text: The medial meniscus is wider anteriorly.

options.label: D
options.text: PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

questions.correct_answer: D. PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.
questions.explanation:
Extracapsular Ligaments

Intracapsular Ligaments
  • Ligamentum Patellae:
    • Attaches from the lower border of the patella to the tibial tuberosity.
    • Continuation of the quadriceps femoris tendon.
  • Lateral (Fibular) Collateral Ligament: (Option B ruled out)
    • Cord-like structure attaching from the femur's lateral condyle to the fibula's head.
    • The Popliteus tendon is located between this ligament and the lateral meniscus.
  • Medial (Tibial) Collateral Ligament:
    • Flat band connecting the medial condyle of the femur to the medial surface of the tibia.
    • Firmly attached to the medial meniscus.
  • Oblique Popliteal Ligament:
    • Tendinous expansion from the semimembranosus muscle, strengthening the posterior capsule.
  • Medial Meniscus
    • Semicircular, wider posteriorly than anteriorly. (Option C ruled out)
    • The peripheral margin adheres to the deep part of the tibial collateral ligament; posterior fibres are continuous with the transverse ligament.
  • Lateral Meniscus
    • Circular.
    • The posterior end is attached to the medial condyle of the femur via two meniscofemoral ligaments; separated from the fibular collateral ligament by the popliteus tendon.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL): (Option A ruled out)
    • It attaches to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia and ascends to the posterior part of the lateral femoral condyle.
    • Prevents posterior displacement of the femur and anterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.
  • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL):
    • It attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia and extends to the anterior part of the medial femoral condyle.
    • Prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.

questions.text: Which muscles are involved in the locking and unlocking of the knee joint?

options.label: A
options.text: Hamstring muscles for both locking and unlocking

options.label: B
options.text: Quadriceps femoris for locking and popliteus for unlocking

options.label: C
options.text: Popliteus for both locking and unlocking

options.label: D
options.text: Soleus for unlocking and hamstring for locking

questions.correct_answer: B. Quadriceps femoris for locking and popliteus for unlocking
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Locking of the Knee Joint

Unlocking of the Knee Joint

Movement

When the foot is on the ground - the medial rotation of the femur on the tibia is locking.

When the foot is on the ground lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia is unlocking.

Phase of Motion

Terminal phase of extension.

Initial phase of flexion.

Muscle Involved

(Option A, C & D)

Quadriceps femoris

Popliteus muscle

Knee Rigidity

The locked knee becomes rigid.

An unlocked knee can be further flexed.

Ligament Tension

All ligaments are taut.

All ligaments are relaxed.

Function

Essential for bearing load during erect posture.

Facilitates the progress of locomotion.
